thread.title: TV Pick of the Day: The Kennedys (BBC One), October 2
thread.title_full: TV Pick of the Day: The Kennedys (BBC One), October 2

author: WMNdellis
title: TV Pick of the Day: The Kennedys (BBC One), October 2
text:
Comments (0) 
The Kennedys (BBC One, 9.30pm) 
'Write what you know,' as the old adage goes, so little wonder some of Britain's best funny folks have seen their lives recreated for the small screen. 
TV offerings about the lives of Lenny Henry (Danny and the Human Zoo) and Danny Baker (Cradle to Grave) have helped spice up the Beeb's schedules. 
Now it's the turn of actress, writer and TV presenter Emma Kennedy. 
Humans and IT Crowd star Katherine Parkinson headlines this six-part comedy about an aspiring family in the 1970s. 
"I grew up on a council estate when they were places of aspirational wonder," explains Emma. "Social housing was simply the greatest start in life a young family could have, and in The Kennedys I hope I have delivered a series that reflects that hope and joy. It's been a sharp thrill from start to finish." 
Loosely based on her 2009 memoirs The Tent, The Bucket and Me, each episode is introduced by 10-year-old Star Wars obsessed tom-boy Emma Kennedy (Lucy Hutchison). 
She is happy to tag along with her much-loved parents, Brenda and Tony Kennedy (Katherine Parkinson and Dan Skinner). 
The family have just moved into a new estate in Stevenage, New Town and arrive to a concrete labyrinth of similar abodes. 
Delighted at the fact they are now on the verge of being considered middle class, they soon embrace community spirit and organise activities for the neighbourhood to get involved in. 
Lending a hand with the laughs are their best friends - an unmarried couple, Tim the 70s alpha-male (Harry Peacock), and the young yet traditional Jenny (Emma Pierson). 
Shola Adewusi and Clive Rowe also star as The Kennedys' unassuming and often confused neighbours, Dee and David. 
Given some of her family's disastrous holidays, there was little wonder Emma Kennedy's early life was such a rich vein of comedy gold. 
At the age of six she was pulled from a French toilet cubicle, aka a hole in the ground, after stumbling around in the dark. 
Her dad put her in a bin bag, tied it under her neck and drove her to a garage forecourt where he hosed her down. 
Years later, after giggling about her disastrous youth with her folks, Emma wrote all the anecdotes down, and the result was The Tent, The Bucket and Me. 
Although the 10 chapters were just about holidays, to avoid repetition Emma decided to change the format for this series. It gave her the chance to add a lot of the non holiday-related anecdotes that couldn't go into the book. 
She also changed the nationality of her French neighbours to Danish, because she's friends with Sofie Grabol, the actress who stars in Euro hit The Killing. It was her idea to make the neighbours a lesbian couple. 
(Grabol wanted a role in the show, but had to drop out due to filming commitments). 
All great sitcoms need a degree of poignancy, and the fact Emma's mum Brenda, who died in May 2014, was offering advice on this series in her final days means the on screen result is also a fine tribute to the off screen family who inspired it.
